question: Explain any five reasons why commerce is important in the life of a nation
answer:
Commerce is very important in the life of any nation because of the following reasons:

(i) Commerce promotes rapid transfer of both oral and written messages through communication.

(ii) Commerce facilitates exchange of goods and services which people all over the nation enjoy whether produced within or outside their own nation.

(iii) The extent of commercial activities determines the wealth/standard of living of a nation.

(iv) Commerce makes for the protection against risk in day - to - day business operations.

(v) Commerce creates an awareness of the existence of goods and services through advertising.

(vi) Commerce ensures that goods produced are stored until needed, thus making sure that there is steady supply of goods for the nation.

(vii) Commerce offers employment to very large number of people in a nation as retailers, wholesalers and bankers.

(viii) Commerce assists people to have money through financial institutions

question:
(a)Give six features of a public company

(b)Explain four reasons for winding up a public limited company
answer:
(a) The features of a public company are:

(i) It has a legal status: It can sue and be sued.

(ii) Liability of members is limited.

(iii) It can issue debentures to be secured by its assets.

(iv) Shares are easily transferable through the stock market.

(v) It files and publishes its annual reports and accounts.

(vii) The minimum membership is two while there is no limit to its membership.

(viii). It must receive its trading certificate to commerce business.

(b) Some of the reasons for winding up a public limited company are:

(i) Shareholders can pass a resolution at a meeting for voluntary liquidation. It can be as a result of the company's inability to pay its debts or is no longer a good investment or if the purpose for which the company was established has been accomplished.

(ii) A company can be liquidated by the court if it can no more honour its obligations, settlement of its debt or if it is formed for illegal purposes.

(iii) The Corporate Affairs Commission can strike out a company's name out of its register.

(iv) If the company does not commence business within a year of its incorporation.

(v) Liquidation can also occur when the number of shareholders fall below the statutory minimum requirement.

(vi) By voluntary winding up, subject to the law court supervision if some shareholders ask the court for it.

question:
Explain five services of each of the following;
(a) Courier firms
(b) NITEL
answer:
The services offered by the following businesses are:

(a) Courier firms:
(i) Courier service companies deliver mails and parcels safely and faster.

(ii) Many of these companies render 24 hours services to members of the public.

(iii) Courier service companies undertake air cargo and bulk shipment of commodities.

(iv) The services of courier companies are more personal and cordial.

(v) Provision of business reply and proof of delivery.

(vi) Courier service companies provides a lot of employment opportunities.

(vii) Banking documents are also handled in order to reduce time taken by banks to process such documents.

(viii) Courier services are rendered in many parts of the country including rural areas.

(b) NITEL:
(i) NITEL provides telephone services to the public.

(ii) Printed messages can be quickly sent from one place to another through telex services.

(iii) NITEL also provides telegram services.

(iv) Live telecast of events can be provided by NITEL e.g Olympic Games, World Cup etc.

(v) Provision of fax services to the public.

(vi) NITEL can lease out telegraph and telex facilities to companies.

(vii) NITEL provides maritime mobile services needed for emergency cases.

question:
(a) Identify four environmental factors that affect business

(b) Explain how each of the factors mentioned in (a) above affects business operations
answer:
(a) Environmental factors which affect business are:

(i) International environment
(ii) Economic Environment
(iii) cultural environment.
(iv) Demographic
(v) Industrial
(vi) Technological
(vii) Infrastructure!
(viii) Political and legal.

(b)(i) Demographic environment: The size and structure of the population determine what to produce and the quantity to be produced.

(ii) Infrastructural environment: For the objectives of a business to be achieved, there must be infrastructural facilities like, sea ports, road, railways, electricity etc.

(iii) Economic environment: This include income distribution, expenditure patterns and saving capacity. The type of economic system adopted whether capitalism, socialism and mixed economy will have significant influence on the firm.

(iv) Technological environment: This makes installed machinery and equipment obsolete, hence businesses adjust to changes in technology.

(v) Political environment: Government policies and actions determine business practices and investment climates in an economy.

(vi) Ecological environment: Physical and climatic changes such as erosion, pollution, desert encroachment etc., have effect on business organisation.

question:
(a) What is an advertising medium?

(b) State any five factors to be considered before choosing a particular advertis-ing medium.

(c) Give eight examples of advertising media
answer:
(a) An advertising medium is a means through which information about goods and services is brought to the awareness of the people.

(b) Factors for consideration when choosing an advertising medium are:

(i) The cost of using any of the media.

(ii) The age group that uses the product.

(iii) The extent of circulation or coverage of the media.

(iv) The target audience - type and social group to which it is aimed.

(v) The number of people the medium can reach.

(vi) The Nature of the products must be taken into consideration.

(vii) The medium or media used by business competitors.

(c) Examples of advertising media are:
(i) Television
(ii) Radio
(iii) Newspaper
(iv) Magazines and journals
(v) Cinema
(vi) Catalogues
(vii) Leaflets, Handbills
(viii) Window display
(ix) Bill boards, posters.
(x) Trade fairs and Exhibi-tions.
(xi) Free samples
(xii) Car cards/ Stickers.

question:
(a) Describe five ways by which commercial banks aid international trade

(b) State and explain five functions of the Nigerian Export Promotion Council
answer:
(a) Commercial banks aid international trade in the following ways:

(i) Commercial banks discount documentary bills, thus ensuring that an exporter receives his money immediately.

(ii) A commercial bank can act as referee to its customers , vouch for their financial status and integrity when foreign business men ask for it.

(iii) They provide commercial credits to export merchants which facilitate payment for goods imported.

(iv) Commercial banks process foreign exchange requests and helps in transfer of funds.

(v) They facilitate overseas business trips through the sales of traveller's cheque.

(vi) They arrange delivery of shipping documents to the importer and help in clearing the goods from the ports authority and customs.

(b) Functions of the Nigerian Export Promotion Council are:

(i) Export marketing activities: The council issues information on the performance of Nigerian export commodities in foreign markets and identifies the barrier and ways of penetrating into new market.

(ii) Export financing and incentives: The council provides export financing facilities and insurance and assists exporters on export costing and pricing problems. It also advises on trade arbitration, shipping and freight.

(iii) Export development activities: The council adopts measures necessary to increase the volume of production from agriculture and ensures the development of raw products from agriculture for export.

(iv) Trade information services: The council provides trade information through publication of trade journals and export directives. It also organises meetings for exporters.

(v) Training activities: The council organizes seminars and workshops on export management for people engaging in foreign trade.

(vi) Publicity of Nigeria Export Promotion Council: It prepares and issues publications on the various activities of NEPC.

question:
(a) Explain five factors which determine the span of control

(b) Give five functions of the personnel department in a business establishment.
answer:
(a) Factors determining span of control are:

(1) The size of an organisation determines the number of surbordinates to be supervised.

(ii) The frequency /number of interpersonal relationship between the manager and his subordinates. determines the effectives of the span of control within the frame work of an organization.

(iii) The training and experience of the manager: A well trained and experienced manager will have a larger number of subordinates under him.

(iv) The higher the education, training and experience of the subordinates the lower the number of the subordinates too .

(v) The amount of time which a manager spends on non-supervisory work determines the number of subordinates he can effectively supervise.

(vi) Jobs of repetitive nature requires less supervision and large number of subordinates to supervise. Complex jobs requires more supervision and less number of subordinates to supervise.

(vii) The type of control which the manager exercises, leadership style over his subordinates and the freedom of decision extended to them, affects the number of subordinates to supervise.

(b) The Personnel Department in a business establishment performs certain functions such as:

(i) Give notice of vacancy
(ii) Human resource planning
(iii) Recruitment
(iv) Selection
(v) Testing
(vi) Interviewing
(vii) Placement
(viii) Training
(ix) Discipline
(x) Appraisal
(xi) Promotion
(xii) Retirement
(xiii) Salary administration
(xiv) Welfare/ Safety.

question:
(a) Give five reasons why a life assurance policy may be taken

(b) Describe any five insurance policies which a large department shop owner may take.
answer:
(a) Life assurance policy may be taken for the following reasons:

(i) It is a useful way of providing for funeral and death expenses.

(ii) It is a useful way of providing for the welfare of the assured's dependants after his death.

(iii) The life assurance policy can be used as collateral for obtaining a bank loan.

(iv) To provide for a lump sum on retirement and a saving for the future.

(v) To provide for loan repayment in the events of death.

(vi) It provides for the repayment of capital on a partner's death.

(vii) Endowment insurance makes provision for permanent disability.

(viii) Group assurance for employees would be paid out of the amount assured in the event of retirement or death of any of them.

(b) Some insurance policies which a large department shop owner may take are:

(i) Burglary and theft: This type of insurance protects losses resulting from goods stolen or damaged through breaking into the shop and those stolen by thieves.

(ii) Bad debts insurance: The insurance company will guarantee to protect the firm or business owner against bad debts.

(iii) Fire insurance: The insurance covers risks associated with fire outbreak that may damage buildings, factories, shops and stocks.

(iv) Fidelity Guarantee: This is the type of insurance taken by firms against possible loss of money through embezzlement or misappropriation of funds by fraudulent employees.

(v) Motor Vehicle Insurance: To protect the business vehicle against risks or injuries to third parties.

(vi) Goods in transit: To cover against accidental damage or loss to goods in transit.

(vii) Consequential loss: This cover against loss of profit as a result of destruction of business or production caused by fire.

(viii) Plate-glass insurance: To cover for replacement of plate-glass windows in the event of damage.

question: Explain five reasons for consumer protection, stating in each case one relevant government law aimed at the enforcement.
answer:
Reasons for consumers' protection are:

(i) Exploitation: The consumers are protected from exploitation by the manufacturers through indiscriminate price increase. This is done through the Price control Act.

(ii) Sub-standard goods: Manufacturers produce goods without taking into consideration the quality desired. The Standard Organization of Nigeria Act checks such practices.

(iii) Deceptive weights and measures: Sellers may use incorrect weights and measurements in selling goods to customers. The Weight and Measures Act of 1963 helps to prevent such practices.

(iv) Sale of harmful food and drugs: Consumers are also protected from dangerous goods, especially drugs. The Foods and Drugs Act protects the customers against such goods being offered for sale to them.

(v) Credit Purchase Agreement: Consumers are often not well informed about the details of such agreement. They may inadvertently sign false credit facilities. The Hire Purchase Act is aimed at protecting the rights of such customers.

(vi) Misleading advertisement: Many claims made by advertisers about the performance of their products are not correct. Trade Description Act was enacted to check such practices.

question:
(a) State five objectives of establishing the Economic Community of West African States

(b) Give five reasons why the Lake Chad Basin Commission was established.
answer:
(a) The objectives of establishing ECOWAS are:

(i) To promote co-operation and development in all fields of economic activity.

(ii) Raise the standard of living of its people.

(iii) To increase and maintain economic stability in the region.

(iv) To have regional economic co-operation.

(v) To abolish obstacles to the free movement of persons, services and capital between member states.

(vi) To harmonise monetary policies as required for the proper functioning of the community.

(vii) To eliminate customs duties and other charges of equivalent effect between member states in respect of importation and exportation of goods.

(viii) To promote sporting activities.

(ix) To maintain political stability.

(x) To help promote international unity.

(b) The Lake Chad Basin Commission was established for the following reasons:

(i) To maintain liaison with members with a view to more effective use of the waters of the basin.

(ii) To undertake development of underground water resources for multiple uses.

(iii) To enhance the agricultural potentials of Lake Chad Basin area for irrigation.

(iv) To contract and maintain dams, wells, boreholes, drainages and irrigation system.

(v) To control pollution of rivers and lakes.

(vi)To teach farmers modern farming methods.

(vii) To draw up common rules of navigation.

(viii) To undertake projects for control of flood and erosion.

(ix) To develop irrigation system for crop and livestock production.
